_metadata.title: Japanese Sword Terminology Glossary
_metadata.description: Technical terms used in Japanese sword (nihonto) documentation, extracted from Juyo and Tokubetsu Juyo translations

terms.definition: Mountings without a tsuba (guard), typically for tanto.
Red lacquer.
A Bitchu Province school active from late Heian through Nanbokucho. Known for chirimen-hada and refined workmanship.
Hollyhock crest; the Tokugawa family emblem.
Coarse, rough nie particles.
Legs; short lines extending from the hamon toward the edge.
A prestigious Yamashiro school in Kyoto, active from late Heian through Kamakura. Known for refined tanto and elegant workmanship.
Wavy, chevron or zigzag grain pattern, characteristic of Gassan school.
Bitchu Province; a region in present-day western Okayama Prefecture, home to the Aoe school.
Bizen Province; a region in present-day southeastern Okayama Prefecture, the most prolific sword-making province.
Single straight groove.
Straight, bar-like utsuri parallel to the blade.
Sanskrit characters; Buddhist seed syllables.
The temper pattern in the kissaki (point) area.
Dark lines in the ji created by concentrations of steel during folding.
Chikuzen Province; a region in present-day Fukuoka Prefecture, home to the Samonji school.
Crepe-like texture, fine and tightly packed grain with a slightly rough appearance.
Clove-shaped pattern resembling the clove spice bud.
Irregular clove pattern.
A medium-sized point, the most common size.
Medium-width straight temper line; a suguha pattern of moderate width.
Feudal lord; provincial ruler.
A matched pair of long and short swords (katana and wakizashi), symbol of samurai status.
Attributed to; traditional attribution without certainty.
Echizen Province; a region in present-day Fukui Prefecture, known for Shinto-era smiths.
Edo period (1603-1868); the era of peace under Tokugawa rule, when Shinto and later Shinshinto swords were made.
A Higo Province school active from Kamakura through Muromachi. Known for Yamato-influenced work.
Etchu Province; a region in present-day Toyama Prefecture, home to the Norishige line.
The collar at the base of the handle, next to the guard.
The fuchi and kashira as a matched set.
The curve of the cutting edge in the kissaki area.
Blister; a raised area caused by forging flaw.
A metal rim or border.
Boat shape; a nakago (tang) shape with a curved profile resembling a boat's hull. Characteristic of Soshu tradition, especially Sadamune.
The tapering of the blade from base to point, giving a sturdy appearance at the base.
Swinging-sleeve shape; a nakago (tang) shape with curved, flowing contours resembling a kimono sleeve. Common in Rai school and Soshu tradition works.
Double groove; two parallel grooves.
Framed signature; the mei portion cut out and inset.
Modern sword; swords made after 1876.
Silver inlay.
The Five Traditions; the main sword-making schools (Yamashiro, Yamato, Bizen, Soshu, Mino).
Ritual chopsticks; Buddhist implements used in fire ceremonies.
Regular, repeated zigzag or sawtooth pattern.
Irregular gunome pattern.
The cutting edge; also the hardened area of the blade.
Chestnut shape with the edge side higher.
Chestnut-shaped end with the edge side higher; a rounded nakago-jiri variant.
The notch on the cutting edge side.
Nie in the hardened edge area.
The side of the tang where the edge faces outward.
The side of the tang where the edge faces inward.
The blade collar that secures the sword in the scabbard.
The boundary line of the hamon; the edge of the tempered area.
Great Bodhisattva Hachiman; the Shinto-Buddhist deity of war, invoked in blade inscriptions.
Grain; the pattern visible in the steel from the folding process.
Standing grain; visible and pronounced hada pattern on the blade surface.
Edge crack; a crack in the hardened edge.
The outer side when the blade is suspended (for tachi).
The inner side when the blade is suspended.
Brush-swept; sweeping lines extending from the boshi.
The temper line pattern visible along the edge, created by differential hardening.
A Yamato school near Hatakeda. Known for masame-heavy forging patterns.
Heian period (794-1185); the era of court culture when Japanese sword-making traditions developed.
Groove carved into the blade.
Diamond lattice pattern file marks.
Higo Province; a region in present-day Kumamoto Prefecture, home to the Enju school.
The flat area between the shinogi and the hamon.
Flat construction without a shinogi ridge, common on tanto and some wakizashi.
Flat sprinkled picture; maki-e level with the surface.
Flat-triangular construction; a rare blade form with flat sides meeting at a ridge.
The convexity or 'meat' of the blade surface, indicating health and remaining material.
Wide straight temper line; a suguha pattern of broad width.
Full temper; hardening that extends over most of the blade surface.
Hizen Province; a region in present-day Saga/Nagasaki Prefectures, home to the Tadayoshi school.
Sacred jewel; a Buddhist wish-fulfilling gem motif carved on blades.
A Shinto-era Yamashiro school, founded by Horikawa Kunihiro. Active in early Edo period.
Carvings or engravings on the blade.
Narrow straight temper line; a suguha pattern of slender width.
Fraying; fine lines extending from the hamon into the ji.
Hyuga Province; a region in present-day Miyazaki Prefecture.
Full temper; the entire kissaki area is hardened.
One-character; famous Bizen school signing with the character 'ichi'.
A stubby, boar-neck shaped point, characteristic of certain Kamakura blades.
Lightning; bright zigzag lines in the hamon.
A peaked or roof-shaped back, the most common form.
Entering-mountain shape; the nakago-jiri has an angular, mountain-like profile.
Mountain-shaped tang end with a notch.
Colored metalwork; polychrome inlay using various metals.
Ise Province; a region in present-day Mie Prefecture, associated with Muramasa.
Stone-surface ground; textured lacquer resembling stone.
Wood-grain pattern in the steel, resembling the grain of a wooden plank.
Wood-grain pattern skin/surface.
Thread-wrapped tachi; formal tachi with wrapped scabbard sections.
The surface area of the blade between the shinogi and the hamon.
Martensite crystals visible in the ji (surface) area, appearing as bright spots.
Positive silhouette openwork.
Dark patches or mottling in the ji area.
Mottled, patchy utsuri pattern.
The base steel of the blade; the steel quality and character.
The surface grain pattern visible on the blade, created by folding.
Same as jigane; the steel of the blade body.
Jizo-head shape; a rounded boshi resembling the head of Jizo statues.
Overlapping, complex clove pattern.
Important; NBTHK designation for significant blades.
Turnip-drop construction; similar to kanmuri-otoshi but with a more pronounced drop near the mune.
Flame-shaped boshi with flame-like patterns.
The turn-back; where the boshi curves back along the mune.
Kaga Province; a region in present-day Ishikawa Prefecture, known for fine koshirae.
Same as kakitoshi; through-groove to tang end.
Groove that runs off the blade into the tang.
Groove that runs through to the tang end.
Square termination; groove ending in a square shape.
A flat, square back.
Kamakura period (1185-1333); the golden age of Japanese sword-making under samurai rule.
A blade form where the back is beveled near the point.
Stylized signature or monogram.
The thickness of the blade at the back (mune).
Layered carving; a technique where multiple carved elements overlap.
The pommel cap at the end of the handle.
Single-beveled edge construction; one side flat like a chisel, rare on swords but common on some tanto.
One-sided chisel carving; beveled line engraving.
A long sword worn edge-up, thrust through the belt. Became standard from the Muromachi period onward.
Lopsided gunome where one side drops more than the other.
Diagonal file marks slanting upward to the right.
Diagonal file marks slanting downward to the right.
Tadpole-head choji; cloves with bulbous heads like tadpoles.
Hair-line engraving; fine incised lines.
A double-edged straight sword, often with religious or ceremonial significance.
Sword carving; depiction of a Buddhist ritual sword.
Sword-tip shape; the nakago-jiri ends in a pointed, sword-like form.
Sword-tip shaped tang end.
Tweezers carving; a decorative pattern resembling tweezers or hair-pulling implements.
Healthy; well-preserved condition with minimal wear.
Decorative file marks; ornamental yasurime added for aesthetic effect rather than functional finishing.
Kii Province; a region in present-day Wakayama Prefecture.
Pheasant thigh; refers to the distinctive tapering shape seen in early Heian to Kamakura period nakago.
Pheasant-thigh shape; a nakago (tang) shape that tapers like a pheasant's thigh, characteristic of early tachi.
Chrysanthemum crest; the Imperial emblem.
Gold-colored metalwork.
Gold pear-skin ground.
Gold inlay.
Golden lines; bright, shiny streaks in the hamon.
Gold-inlaid signature; attribution added in gold inlay.
Horizontal file marks.
Straight-cut tang end.
Paulownia crest; an imperial and government emblem.
An ancient blade form with a triangular cross-section, found mainly on early ken.
The point or tip section of the blade.
Forging; the process of folding and welding the steel to create the blade.
Forging crack; separation in the laminated steel.
Expert attribution; formal appraisal of unsigned blades.
Flaw; defect or damage in the blade.
Old Aoe; early Bitchu school work.
Small, short ashi.
Old Bizen; early Bizen school work before Ichimonji.
Small clove pattern.
Small gunome pattern.
Fine, small wood-grain pattern.
A small point, typical of Heian and early Kamakura period blades.
Small, rounded turn-back.
Small irregular pattern.
Fine, small burl-grain pattern.
Small, fine nie particles.
Made predominantly of small nie.
Small, gentle wave pattern.
A short tachi, smaller than a standard tachi but larger than a wakizashi.
A hair-arranging implement fitted into the scabbard.
The mouth of the scabbard; where the blade enters.
The end cap of the scabbard.
Short groove in the lower blade section.
Short groove in the lower part of the blade.
Mountings; the complete set of fittings and furniture for a sword.
Curvature concentrated near the base of the blade, typical of early tachi.
Old sword; blades made before approximately 1596.
A small utility knife fitted into the scabbard.
Offset pattern; hamon that appears to miss or skip.
Chestnut-shaped tang end; rounded.
Dragon coiled around a sword; Buddhist deity representation.
The knob on the scabbard through which the sageo passes.
Black lacquer.
Antler or stag-beetle horn shape; a decorative V-shaped element found in carvings and helmet crests.
The notches at the base of the blade where it meets the tang.
The machi has been moved; the blade shortened by moving the notches.
Sprinkled picture; lacquer technique using gold/silver powder.
Marici; a Buddhist deity of light and invisibility, carved on blades for protection.
Round termination; groove ending in a rounded shape.
A rounded back.
Straight grain pattern running parallel to the blade length.
Straight grain pattern skin/surface.
The signature inscribed on the tang.
Famous blade; a sword of exceptional fame and quality.
Register of signatures; reference book of smith signatures.
Peg hole(s) in the tang for securing the handle.
Ornamental grip fittings placed under the handle wrapping.
Irregular, mixed temper pattern.
Irregular pattern continuing into the boshi.
Irregular, wavy utsuri pattern that mirrors the hamon.
Irregular temper line; general term for non-straight hamon.
The width of the blade.
A Bingo Province school active from Kamakura through Muromachi. Known for tight ko-itame and refined suguha.
Mikawa Province; a region in present-day eastern Aichi Prefecture.
Mino Province; a region in present-day Gifu Prefecture, one of the Five Traditions (Gokaden).
A Yamashiro school of the Shinto era, known for elegant suguha and fine workmanship.
The three-piece set of kozuka, kogai, and menuki.
A three-sided back with a flat top.
Burl or swirling grain pattern, like knots in wood.
Burl-grain pattern skin/surface.
Momoyama period (1573-1603); a brief era of lavish culture bridging Muromachi and Edo.
Family crest; heraldic emblem.
The striking portion of the blade, approximately the upper third.
Double-edged construction, typical of ken.
The width of the blade at the base (machi).
Patternless or invisible grain, extremely fine forging.
Unsigned; no signature on the tang.
The back of the blade (opposite the cutting edge).
The notch on the back (mune) side.
Tempering along the back (mune) of the blade.
Muromachi period (1336-1573); era of mass sword production and rise of the uchigatana.
Musashi Province; a region covering present-day Tokyo, Saitama, and eastern Kanagawa.
No curvature; a straight blade.
A weapon with a blade similar to a tachi but with an exceptionally long handle wrapped in cord.
Flowing grain pattern, where the hada appears to flow along the blade.
The length of the blade, measured in a straight line from the machi to the tip.
A polearm with a curved blade, used primarily by warrior monks and women of samurai families.
Naginata-style groove; a groove pattern imitating the form found on naginata blades.
Naginata construction; a blade form with a reverse curve, originally for naginata but sometimes found on swords.
The tang; the part of the blade that fits into the handle.
The end/tip of the tang.
Center curvature; deepest point of curve is in the middle of the blade.
Fish-roe pattern; tiny raised dots covering a surface.
Fish-roe ground; a surface covered with nanako pattern.
Northern and Southern Courts period (1336-1392); era of large, impressive blades.
Pear-skin ground; lacquer with gold flakes creating texture.
Pear-skin texture, a fine, granular surface appearance.
Individual crystals of martensite visible as bright, sparkling particles.
Made predominantly of nie; a bright, crystalline hamon appearance.
Nie-dominant; more nie than nioi in the hamon.
Collapsed nie; areas where nie structure has broken down.
Boshi with collapsed or disintegrated nie.
Nie lines; streaks formed by concentrations of nie.
Utsuri formed by nie particles, characteristic of Yamashiro work.
Double-edge pattern; a secondary line parallel to the main hamon.
The flesh or meat of the blade; the convex surface thickness.
The distribution of thickness/meat across the blade, indicating robustness.
Extremely fine martensite particles not individually visible, creating a misty appearance.
Made predominantly of nioi; a soft, misty hamon appearance.
Nioi-dominant; more nioi than nie in the hamon.
The visible edge of the hamon where hardened steel meets softer steel.
A Yamashiro school active from late Kamakura into Muromachi, often showing Soshu influence.
Gentle, wave-like undulations in the hamon.
Waves that extend deeply into the blade.
Cloth-pattern inlay; metal pressed into cross-hatched surface.
Large clove pattern.
Large gunome pattern.
Large, coarse wood-grain pattern.
A large, extended point, characteristic of Nanbokucho period blades.
Large, rounded turn-back.
Large irregular pattern.
Large, coarse burl-grain pattern.
Large, pronounced wave pattern.
Steeply angled diagonal file marks.
Greatly shortened; significantly reduced in length.
A Yamato school associated with Omiya shrine. Includes Morikuni and later generations.
The front or outer side (facing out when worn).
Certificate of authenticity; appraisal document.
Folded-back signature; the original mei preserved when shortening.
The most prolific Bizen school, active from Kamakura through Edo. Includes sub-branches like Nagamitsu, Kagemitsu, and later generations.
A major Yamashiro school in Kyoto, active from mid-Kamakura through Nanbokucho. Known for elegant nie-deki work.
Lotus pedestal; Buddhist lotus throne carving.
Wax-color finish; highly polished black lacquer.
Founder of the Samonji school in Chikuzen. Known for bold Soshu-influenced style with prominent nie.
Bright, clear, and vivid; describes a well-defined hamon.
Sagami Province; a region in present-day Kanagawa Prefecture, home to the Soshu tradition.
The cord attached to the scabbard for securing to the belt.
Reversed or slanting ashi.
The width of the blade near the point.
Curvature concentrated toward the point.
Rayskin; the textured skin used to wrap handles.
A Chikuzen Province school founded by Sa. Known for Soshu-influenced work and powerful hamon.
Three-cedar pattern; groups of three pointed elements.
An early Yamashiro school in Kyoto, legendary for Sanjo Munechika. Active in late Heian period.
Triple-pronged vajra sword; a Buddhist ritual sword carving with a three-pronged hilt.
The outer side when the blade is thrust through the belt (for katana).
The inner side when the blade is thrust through the belt.
Scabbard; the sheath that holds the blade.
Scabbard inscription; attribution written on the storage scabbard.
Lengthwise file marks parallel to the tang.
Spacers placed on either side of the tsuba.
Explanation; the descriptive text accompanying a sword evaluation.
An alloy of copper and gold, patinated to a deep blue-black.
An alloy of copper and silver, patinated to grey.
Tight; describes a compact, well-controlled hamon.
Bend; curvature caused by lateral stress.
The ridge line running along the blade that divides the ji (flat) from the shinogi-ji.
The flat area between the shinogi and the mune.
The most common blade construction with a distinct ridge line (shinogi) running along the blade.
Bamboo-joint cut file marks; a specific pattern of horizontal file marks.
New-new sword; blades made approximately 1781-1876.
New sword; blades made from approximately 1596-1780.
Shintogo Kunimitsu; a Soshu smith who studied under Masamune. Known for fine tanto and wakizashi.
Whitish, faint utsuri.
Sunken relief carving.
A Mino school descended from Soshu tradition via Kaneuji. Known for hitatsura and bold nie.
Similar to shinogi-zukuri but without a yokote line, giving a continuous curve to the point.
Red lacquer signature; attribution in red lacquer.
Companion groove; a shorter groove alongside another.
The curvature of the blade.
A matched set of fittings.
Sagami Province tradition; the Kamakura school.
Plain copper.
Bamboo-blind pattern; vertical streaks in the hamon.
Bamboo-blind pattern; vertical streaks in the hamon resembling a rolled bamboo blind. Alternate form of sudare-ba.
Straight; the boshi runs straight to the point.
Straight temper line running parallel to the edge.
Straight temper line tendency; primarily straight with slight variations.
Cross-hatched or intersecting file marks.
Diagonal file marks.
Openwork; pierced or cut-through design.
Plain sword; simple sword carving without elaborate details.
Extended length, longer than the standard for the blade type.
Shortened length, shorter than the standard for the blade type.
Flowing sand; sweeping lines of nie in the hamon.
Shortened tang; the blade has been cut down.
A long sword worn edge-down, suspended from the belt. The primary battlefield sword of the Heian through Muromachi periods.
Tachi-style mountings for a suspended sword.
A Hizen Province school founded by Hashimoto Tadayoshi. Known for refined Shinto-era blades.
Greatly tired; significant wear from repeated polishing.
A Yamato school near Taima temple. Known for masame and robust construction.
High-relief carving.
Raised sprinkled picture; maki-e built up in relief.
Hawk-feather pattern; V-shaped file marks.
Jewel dragon; a dragon depicted with or pursuing a sacred jewel (hoju).
Cutting test inscription; record of test cuts inscribed on tang.
Test cutting; evaluating a blade's cutting ability.
Cod-roe belly; a nakago (tang) shape with a rounded, full contour on the ha (edge) side, resembling a belly full of fish roe.
A dagger or knife, typically under 30 cm in blade length.
Hand-slanting file marks; diagonal yasurime created by hand pressure.
A Yamato school centered at Tegai temple in Nara. Known for masame and religious motifs.
Scattered tempering; isolated patches of hardening above the hamon.
Pointed boshi.
Pointed gunome pattern.
Pointed, angular peaks in the hamon.
Burnished maki-e; design polished flush with lacquer.
Sword/blade; general term for Japanese swords.
Especially Important; highest NBTHK designation.
Even curvature along the entire blade length, like a torii gate.
Swordsmith; master sword maker.
The sword guard.
Handle; the grip portion of the sword.
Handle wrapping cord; the braid wrapped over the same.
Claw or talon carving.
Original, unaltered tang; the blade has not been shortened.
Katana-style mountings for a thrust-through-belt sword.
Projections; areas where the hamon extends into the ji.
Reverse curvature where the edge curves inward, common on tanto.
Relief carving; design raised above the surface of the blade.
Plug; metal inserted to repair a flaw.
A Yamashiro family of metalworkers and sword makers active in Momoyama and Edo periods.
A blade form with the shinogi line dropping sharply near the point, creating a cormorant-neck profile.
The back or inner side (facing the body when worn).
Moistness; a soft, subdued quality in the nioiguchi where the boundary between tempered and untempered steel appears blurred or hazy.
A misty, cloud-like reflection in the ji, especially characteristic of Bizen work.
Applied overlay; metal shapes soldered onto the surface.
A short sword, typically 30-60 cm in blade length. Often paired with a katana as part of a daisho set.
Ring curvature; warping from heat or stress.
The hardened edge area; the tempered portion of the blade.
The beginning of the hamon at the base of the blade.
The width of the tempered area (hamon).
Area where the hamon drops below the ha-machi.
No turn-back; the hamon ends at the tip without returning.
Unrefined copper; mountain copper.
A spear with various blade shapes.
File marks on the tang.
Leaves; leaf-shaped formations in the hamon.
The line separating the main blade from the kissaki.
Running water; isolated areas of nie in the ji above the hamon.
Inlay; embedding one metal into another.
